scenarioDescription:
The HD 163607 Exoplanetary System


Overview

HD 163607 is a star with 1.12 times the mass of the Sun, and 1.76 times its radius. It is located 221.09 light years away from the solar system and is estimated to be 8.6 billion years old, as compared to the Sun which is roughly 4.6 billion years old.

HD 163607 is known to have 2 exoplanets in orbit around it.


Exoplanets in the HD 163607 system


HD 163607 b

HD 163607 b was discovered by the W. M. Keck Observatory observatory, in 2012-01, using the radial velocity method. Its semi-major axis is 0.36 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. The mass of HD 163607 b is 249.185 times the mass of Earth. The radius of HD 163607 b is 13.900 that of Earth. At more than 50 Earth masses, HD 163607 b is a gas giant, a planet whose mass is mostly made up of hydrogen and helium, like Jupiter and Saturn in our solar system.


HD 163607 c

HD 163607 c was discovered by the W. M. Keck Observatory observatory, in 2012-01, using the radial velocity method. Its semi-major axis is 2.39 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. The mass of HD 163607 c is 699.918 times the mass of Earth. The radius of HD 163607 c is 13.300 that of Earth. At more than 50 Earth masses, HD 163607 c is a gas giant, a planet whose mass is mostly made up of hydrogen and helium, like Jupiter and Saturn in our solar system.
description: 3D visualisation and gravity simulation of the exoplanet system HD 163607, which contains 2 exoplanets and was discovered by the W. M. Keck Observatory.
name: HD 163607 - System With 2 Exoplanets
